text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Michael Wamalwa, chairman of opposition FORD-Kenya party, challenges parliamentary allies of Raila Odinga to join him in defecting from FORD-Kenya and joining National Development Party.
- Highway gangsters ambush nine members of religious sect and kill 14-year-old boy.
- One more person dies in raid on Kainuk trading centre, bringing to five the number of people killed in recent raids in district.
- Raila Odinga after defection takes over opposition party FORD-Kenya offices in slum areas of Kibera and Mathare.
- Government urged to allow citizens who still hold old identity cards to vote in general election.
- Police in Kiambu hold more than 23 suspects in connection with killing of two people.
- Raila Odinga declares that his defection from fractured FORD-Kenya was not result of cowardice but was to avoid legal tussles with party chairman Wamalwa.
- Secretary-general of ruling party Kenya African National Union says scrapping posts of district chairmen is aimed at strengthening party at grassroots level.
- President Moi says shortage of staple food is one of main challenges facing Kenya in new year.
